repnme.cdata!:
Cote D'Ivoire - Economic Recovery
            Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the project were as
            follows: the outcome was unsatisfactory, the sustainability
            was unlikely, the institutional development impact was
            negligible, the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the
            borrower performance was unsatisfactory. The lessons learned
            indicate that the conflict that started three months after
            project approval essentially blocked policymaking and reform
            implementation and led to a substantial decline in
            population welfare. The government commitment to reforms is
            critical if policy actions are to be sustained but reform
            priorities can change significantly in the wake of a war
            situation. Country volatility was a risk clearly identified
            in the President's Report of the Economic Recovery
            Project (ERC) and the I-CAS and draft I-TSS: there was a
            recognition of a continuous risk that the national
            reconciliation process may stall or reverse. Selectivity and
            realism are essential when the reform agenda is vast and
            available capacity might be limited compared with the
            agenda, especially in volatile political situations. The
            design of a quick-disbursing credit in multiple tranches
            seems appropriate for countries which are moving slowly or
            taking only partial measures for their reforms, or when risk
            of non-implementation is high. It took a long time to
            convince the government of the need for the Bank's exit
            from this operation as country conditions effectively
            blocked project implementation. The ERC was just one of a
            broader Bank strategy and its collection of instruments for
            the pursuit of its dialogue with a country in a
            post-conflict situation. The Bank could possibly envisage a
            more modulated response in the design of specific projects
            in the context of volatile country situations.

repnme.cdata!:
Cote d'Ivoire - Economic Recovery
            Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Economic Recovery Program of the
            Government of Cote d'Ivoire, supported btthis Economic
            Recovery Credit aims at: a) creating the conditions for
            renewed broad-based growth driven by the rural economy and a
            private sector that is more confident about the future; b)
            improving public sector delivery with participation of local
            communities; and c) improving efficiency and accountability
            in public resource management. THE ERC is a quick-disbursing
            credit of three tranches. Its proceeeds will help the
            Government meet the costs of the economic recovery program
            within a stanle macroeconomic environment; and increase
            resource allocation to the priority poverty-sensitive
            sectors of primary education and primary health (including
            the fight against HIV/AIDS). Successful implementation of
            the ERP supported by the ERC should: 1) increase incomes and
            employment opportunities in the rural economy and create the
            conditions for strengthened private sector activity; 2)
            expand access to and improve the quality of primary
            education and health services, while strengthening local
            community participation in the delivery of such services;
            and 3) improve budget formulation, execution, and monitoring
            and reporting, while strengthening accountability.
